data.title: Edmund Verney (1590-1642)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for Edmund Verney born 1590  died 1642 Edge Hill, Warwickshire, England including ancestors + descendants + 1 photos + 2 genealogist comments + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Born 1 Jan 1590 [location unknown]

Ancestors Descendants

Profile last modified 16 Jun 2024 | Created 26 Apr 2015

This page has been accessed 1,113 times.

Contents

1 Biography

1.1 Siblings

1.2 Marriage

1.2.1 children

1.3 Events

1.4 Death

2 Sources

Biography

Edmund Verney is Notable.

Edmund Verney, b. 1590, was the son of:[1]

Sir Edmund Verney of Pendley Manor near Tring, Buckinghamshire,[1]

and his third wife Mary Blakeney.[1]

"Sir Edmund Verney . . b. 9 Nov. 1613, 1st s. of Sir Edmund Verney kinght-marshal, of Middle Claydon and Covent Garden. . . (history of Parliament)

Siblings

He had an elder half-brother Sir Francis Verney (d. 1615), and two elder half-sisters on his mother's side,

Ann Turvill m. Sir John Leeke of Edmonton,[1]

Ursula St. Barbe m. stepbrother Sir Francis Verney.[1]

Marriage

He married Margaret Denton, daughter of Sir Thomas Denton of Hillesden, Buckinghamshire on 14 December 1612, [2] with whom he had six sons, and six daughters (in all, ten surviving children). Margaret died in 1641, and was buried at Claydon.[3]

children

His children include:

Sir Ralph Verney, 1st Baronet (1613–1696)

Henry Verney

Sir Edmund Verney (1616–1649) who commanded the troops Royalist infantry in Drogheda at the Siege of Drogheda and was slain during the final assault (mentioned in Cromwell's letter to John Bradshaw, Esquire, President of the Council of State, dated 16 September 1649).[4]

Susanna (Mrs Alport)

Penelope (Lady Osborn, Mrs Denton)

Margaret (Lady Margaret Elmes

Cary

m. Sir Thomas Gardiner, son of Sir Thomas Gardiner (1591 - d. 1652) & Rebecca Child.[5][6]

Mary

m. Robert Lloyd

Elizabeth

m. Rev. Charles Adams

This and extensive further information about the children of Sir Edmund Verney can be found here.[7]

Events

Knighted by King James in 1611, Edmund was sent to Madrid, and returned to join the household of Henry Frederick, Prince of Wales, to which his uncle Francis Verney was one of the falconers.[8]When Henry died in 1612, Edmund became a gentleman of the privy chamber to Charles, Duke of York, later Charles I.[9]

From 1620 he made his family home at Middle Claydon, Buckinghamshire (which the Giffard family had held by lease from the Verneys[10]), where he was the near neighbour of Sir Thomas Chaloner of Steeple Claydon.[11] He was severely in debt by the early 1620s.

In 1623, he accompanied Charles and the Duke of Buckingham to Spain to court the Infanta Maria. While there, he protected a dying Englishman from a Catholic priest by punching the priest in the face, which did not endear him to the Spaniards.

Upon his return, he was elected Member of Parliament for Buckingham in 1624, and for New Romney in 1625. After the coronation of Charles that year, he was appointed Knight Marshal of England for life, the duties of which office required him to be extensively at court. He was returned for Aylesbury in 1629. Despite his income from the Knight Marshalsy, several business ventures ended in failure, and his debts were largely unrelieved.[12]

With the approach of the English Civil War, he found himself in a painful conflict. While personally loyal to the King, he resisted the Laudian religious policies. Verney was returned to the Short Parliament and then the Long Parliament as member for Wycombe, and often found himself in opposition to the King.

At the outbreak of war, Verney remained loyal to King Charles, but his eldest son Ralph joined the Parliamentary forces.

Death

Made standard-bearer of the Royal army, Verney was killed at the Battle of Edgehill. According to the tradition of his family, his body was never identified, except for his severed hand, found still grasping the banner.[13]

Claydon House was the family seat in Middle Claydon

Sources

↑ 1.0 1.1 1.2 1.3 1.4 W.H. Rylands (ed.), The Visitation of the County of Buckingham made in 1634 by John Philipot and William Riley, Harleian Society Volume LVIII (for 1909) (London 1909), Verney, p.122-23

↑ W.H. Rylands, Visitation of Buckinghamshire

↑ "Gardiner," in Le Neve's Knights, 1873, p. 95. WikiTree.com. Pedigree.

↑ "Gardiner," in Vis. of London, p. 299. Archive.org. eBook.

The Civil War.--v. 3. The Commonwealth, 1650-1660.--v. 4. From the Restoration to the Revolution, 1660-1696 Publisher London : Longmans, Green. Volume 2. https://archive.org/stream/memoirsofverneyf02vernuoft#page/52/mode/2up

↑ Frances Parthenope Verney, Memoirs of the Verney Family During the Civil War (Longmans, Green & Co., London 1892), 1, p. 69 ff., at p. 70. A falconer of this name is mentioned in 'An Abstract or brief Declaration of the present State of His Majesty's Revenue' (printed 1651), in Sir Walter Scott (ed.), A Collection of Scarce and Valuable Tracts on the Most Entertaining Subjects, 2nd Edn., 2 Vols (T. Cadell & W. Davies, London 1809), Vol. 1 pp. 364-400, at p. 393.

↑ F.P. Verney, Memoirs of the Verney Family Vol. 1, Chapters 1 and 2, and at p.33-3
